question.title: How to sort a List/ArrayList?
question.body:
I have a List of Double objects in Java. I want to sort the ArrayList in descending order.

Input ArrayList:

List<Double> testList = new ArrayList();

testList.add(0.5);
testList.add(0.2);
testList.add(0.9);
testList.add(0.1);
testList.add(0.1);
testList.add(0.1);
testList.add(0.54);
testList.add(0.71);
testList.add(0.71);
testList.add(0.71);
testList.add(0.92);
testList.add(0.12);
testList.add(0.65);
testList.add(0.34);
testList.add(0.62);

The out put should be like this

0.92
0.9
0.71
0.71
0.71
0.65
0.62
0.54
0.5
0.34
0.2
0.12
0.1
0.1
0.1

answers.body:
tl;dr

In modern Java:

List                          // Literals syntax, instead of multiple `.add` calls. 
.of( 0.5 , 0.2 , 0.9 , 0.1 , 0.1 , 0.1 , 0.54 , 0.71 , 0.71 , 0.71 , 0.92 , 0.12 , 0.65 , 0.34 , 0.62 )
.stream()                     // Auto-boxing in line above produced `Double` objects, here fed into a stream as `Double` object elements.
.sorted()                     // Elements of stream are sorted using natural-order.
.toList()                     // Returns an unmodifiable `List` object of an unspecified `List` implementation class. 
.reversed()                   // For descending order, return a view onto that collection, in reverse order. Does *not* actually create a new collection, so very fast.
.forEach( IO :: println );    // Streams our list of `Double` objects, passing each to the `println` method of the `IO` class that is a convenient alternative to `System.out`.

When run:

0.92
0.9
0.71
0.71
0.71
0.65
0.62
0.54
0.5
0.34
0.2
0.12
0.1
0.1
0.1

Literals syntax

In Java 9+, we can use convenient literals syntax for your input of double primitive values. As always, auto-boxing converts the primitives to Double objects.

List < Double > inputs = List.of( 0.5 , 0.2 , 0.9 , 0.1 , 0.1 , 0.1 , 0.54 , 0.71 , 0.71 , 0.71 , 0.92 , 0.12 , 0.65 , 0.34 , 0.62 );

Stream#toList

From your list, you can get a sorted stream, as discussed in other Answers. But those other Answers use the older longer syntax .collect(Collectors.toList()). You can now use the briefer syntax .toList() in Java 16+.

List < Double > sorted = inputs.stream().sorted().toList();

This sorting works because the Double class implements Comparable. Its compareTo method means the Double objects know how to sort themselves, known as “natural order”.

You want descending order, with larger numbers first rather than last. So pass a Comparator to reverse the sort order.

List < Double > sorted = inputs.stream().sorted( Comparator.reverseOrder() ).toList();

Let's reformat that for clarity.

List < Double > sorted = 
    inputs
        .stream()
        .sorted( 
            Comparator.reverseOrder() 
        )
        .toList();

When run:

sorted = [0.92, 0.9, 0.71, 0.71, 0.71, 0.65, 0.62, 0.54, 0.5, 0.34, 0.2, 0.12, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1]

SequencedCollection

Java 21+ brings sequenced collections (video).

Now List, and therefore ArrayList/LinkedList, extend from SequencedCollection interface.

If appropriate to your situation, you may want to refer to your list as the more general SequencedCollection.

SequencedCollection < Double > sorted = inputs.stream().sorted().toList();

For example, if later you decide to eliminate duplicate values in your data, you could simply swap out the List with a SequencedSet such as TreeSet — without breaking your existing code base. This works because a SequencedSet is also a SequencedCollection.

SequencedCollection < Double > sorted = new TreeSet<>( inputs ) ;  // `TreeSet` automatically sorts while also eliminating duplicates.

List#reversed

You want your list in descending order, rather than ascending. In code above we used Comparator.reverseOrder() to accomplish that goal within our stream.

That is fine. But, FYI, there is an alternative with sequenced collections. The SequencedCollection interface requires the method reversed which returns a reverse-ordered view of the collection.

This means we could create the reversed view after the stream has finished. Just an option; not necessarily better in this particular case. (It is briefer code; I suppose that is one advantage.)

List < Double > sorted = inputs.stream().sorted().toList().reversed();

Be aware that as a view, the new reversed collection is actually the same original collection. The view and the original are one and the same. So changing the original changes the reversed one as well. (In this particular case, that aspect is irrelevant. In our code above, no reference remains pointing to the List produced by toList. All that remains reachable is our reversed view.)

IO

Java 25 gave us the handy convenience class IO for easier access to the console.

You may choose to use its print, println, and readln methods in place of System.out/System.in.

sorted.forEach( IO :: println ) ;  // Dump to console.

Example code

Putting all these ideas together:

List   
.of( 0.5 , 0.2 , 0.9 , 0.1 , 0.1 , 0.1 , 0.54 , 0.71 , 0.71 , 0.71 , 0.92 , 0.12 , 0.65 , 0.34 , 0.62 )
.stream() 
.sorted()     
.toList()                   
.reversed()                  
.forEach( IO :: println );

When run:

0.92
0.9
0.71
0.71
0.71
0.65
0.62
0.54
0.5
0.34
0.2
0.12
0.1
0.1
0.1

With Eclipse Collections you could create a primitive double list, sort it and then reverse it to put it in descending order. This approach would avoid boxing the doubles.

MutableDoubleList doubleList =
    DoubleLists.mutable.with(
        0.5, 0.2, 0.9, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.54, 0.71,
        0.71, 0.71, 0.92, 0.12, 0.65, 0.34, 0.62)
        .sortThis().reverseThis();
doubleList.each(System.out::println);

Updated: Sept. 2023

Since the 10.3 release, Eclipse Collections supports indirect sorting of primitive lists.

@Test
public void sortDoubleListInDescendingOrder()
{
    MutableDoubleList testList = DoubleLists.mutable
            .with(0.5, 0.2, 0.9, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.54, 0.71, 0.71,
                  0.71, 0.92, 0.12, 0.65, 0.34, 0.62);

    DoubleList expected = DoubleLists.mutable
            .with(0.92, 0.9, 0.71, 0.71, 0.71, 0.65, 0.62, 0.54,
                  0.5, 0.34, 0.2, 0.12, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1);

    Assertions.assertNotEquals(expected, testList);

    testList.sortThis((i, j) -> -Double.compare(i, j));

    Assertions.assertEquals(expected, testList);
}

End Update

If you want a List<Double>, then the following would work.

List<Double> objectList =
    Lists.mutable.with(
        0.5, 0.2, 0.9, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.54, 0.71,
        0.71, 0.71, 0.92, 0.12, 0.65, 0.34, 0.62)
        .sortThis(Collections.reverseOrder());
objectList.forEach(System.out::println);

If you want to keep the type as ArrayList<Double>, you can initialize and sort the list using the ArrayListIterate utility class as follows:

ArrayList<Double> arrayList =
    ArrayListIterate.sortThis(
            new ArrayList<>(objectList), Collections.reverseOrder());
arrayList.forEach(System.out::println);

Note: I am a committer for Eclipse Collections.

Using lambdas (Java 8), and stripping it down to the barest of syntax (the JVM will infer plenty in this case), you get:

Collections.sort(testList, (a, b) -> b.compareTo(a));

A more verbose version:

// Implement a reverse-order Comparator by lambda function
Comparator<Double> comp = (Double a, Double b) -> {
    return b.compareTo(a);
};

Collections.sort(testList, comp);

The use of a lambda is possible because the Comparator interface has only a single method to implement, so the VM can infer which method it's implementing. Since the types of the params can be inferred, they don't need to be stated, i.e. (a, b) instead of (Double a, Double b). And since the lambda body has only a single line, and the method is expected to return a value, the return is inferred and the braces aren't necessary.
